titleStmt.title: Five strange and wonderful prodigies: or, A full and true relation of supernatural sights and aparitions lately seen in the air viz. Tvvo great armies drawn up in battalia, and seeming ready to engage each other, beheld for some hours, by several thousands of people: with dreadful noises heard, like the discharge of cannons and musquets, accompanied with hideous crys and howling. As also a fiery-bullet of a most vast magnitude violently rushing through the air, and at last with a most terrible crack breaking into a thousand pieces, to the unspeakable terror of the amazed spectators. As it is certified by several persons of quality. With an astrological judgement thereupon.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Five strange and wonderful prodigies: or, A full and true relation of supernatural sights and aparitions lately seen in the air viz. Tvvo great armies drawn up in battalia, and seeming ready to engage each other, beheld for some hours, by several thousands of people: with dreadful noises heard, like the discharge of cannons and musquets, accompanied with hideous crys and howling. As also a fiery-bullet of a most vast magnitude violently rushing through the air, and at last with a most terrible crack breaking into a thousand pieces, to the unspeakable terror of the amazed spectators. As it is certified by several persons of quality. With an astrological judgement thereupon.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Strange and Wonderful PRODIGIES: OR, A Full and True Relation of Supernatural Sights and Aparitions lately Å¿een in the AIR: VIZ. Tvvo Great Armies drawn up in Battalia, and Å¿eeming ready to Engage each other, beheld for Å¿ome hours, by Å¿everal thouÅ¿ands of People: With dreadful NoiÅ¿es heard, like the diÅ¿charge of Cannons and MuÅ¿quets, accompanied with hideous Crys and Howlings. As alÅ¿o a FIERY-BULLET Of a moÅ¿t vaÅ¿t Magnitude violently ruÅ¿hing through the Air, and at laÅ¿t with a moÅ¿t terrible crack breaking into a thouÅ¿and pieces, to the unÅ¿peakable Terror of the amazed Spectators. As it is certified by Å¿everal perÅ¿ons of quality. With an AÅ¿trological Judgement thereupon.
London, Printed for G. H. in the Year, 1673.

div.head: Wonderful Prodigies: OR, Supernatural Apparitions, &c.
div.p:
THat there have been Å¿trange and unaccountable Å¿ights and apparitions many times beheld in the Air, is a truth Å¿o well voucht as not to be denyed by any, but thoÅ¿e obÅ¿tinate Scepticks, who rather than part with a darling fancy of Å¿ingularity, care not if they give the Lye to all Antiquity, proclaim the reÅ¿t of Mankind, Fools or Mad-men, or diÅ¿beleive the TeÅ¿timonies of their own Å¿ences: JoÅ¿ephus an HiÅ¿torian of unqueÅ¿tion'd fidelity, tells us of a flaming Sword that hung many days over the City of JeruÅ¿alem: Immediately before it's fatal deÅ¿truction by VeÅ¿paÅ¿ian, and 'tis Å¿ufficiently known what variety of prodigies proceeded the laÅ¿t moÅ¿t bloody Wars in Germany:
Certainly the Doctrine of Methors affords but little Å¿atisfaction to our inquities, after the CauÅ¿es, amazing apparences, PhiloÅ¿ophy is nonpluÅ¿t, and gives too lean an account when it tells us of Reflections in watriÅ¿h Clouds of Exhalations, moiÅ¿t clammy SubÅ¿tances drawn up by the Suns heat, and Å¿et on Fire in the upper Region, &c. TheÅ¿e may produce an Ignis Fatuus, or Jack with the Lanthorn: A falling Star, Å¿ome unuÅ¿ual flaÅ¿hings, CorruÅ¿cations, Mock-moons, and Halo's or Sircles about the Sun, and the like: But for thoÅ¿e Extraordinary Phoenomina; we muÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ign Å¿ome other adequate CauÅ¿es, and certainly we Å¿hall not Err if we Å¿ay that All mighty God offended with mens Impiety Exhibites (whether by the MiniÅ¿try of Angels or otherwiÅ¿e) theÅ¿e Å¿trange Å¿ights as warnings to admoniÅ¿h them of Severe Judgements impending, unleÅ¿Å¿e prevented by Å¿incere Repentance and Amendment.

How neer the Kingdom of Poland was, but the other year to the Confines of Ruine, none can be Ignorant, that at all obÅ¿erve the Å¿everal Å¿tones of fate acted on the great Theater of the World, DomeÅ¿tick Factions, and an overbearing InvaÅ¿ion by the Turk had reduc'd that miÅ¿erable Nation almoÅ¿t to Extremity, being forced (beÅ¿ides an Ignominious tribute) to yeild up and proÅ¿titute a large part of their Territories to the LuÅ¿t of that InÅ¿atiate MonÅ¿ter of the EaÅ¿t, Å¿ince that, God has offered thoÅ¿e People a Breathing time of peace, and in a great meaÅ¿ure abated the AnimoÅ¿ities of the NobleÅ¿s and diÅ¿contents of the Vulgar, what uÅ¿e they have made of theÅ¿e Mercies, or returns of Gratitude to Heaven we know not: 'Tis certain great deliverances oblige Sinners to Å¿uitable acknowledgements and Improvements, which providence Å¿eems now to Exact,
by Alarming them with the moÅ¿t dreadful prodigies that have been heard of in our age. A full and true accompt whereof as it was lately TranÅ¿mitted to us in Å¿everal Letters from thence, be pleaÅ¿ed to take as follows.

On the third of October laÅ¿t paÅ¿t at the Town of PoÅ¿en, and round about for above ten miles diÅ¿tance from thence, about five of the Clock in the morning was Å¿een the perfect appearance of two great Armies in the Air: The Sky was very clear and Å¿carce a Cloud to be Å¿een above the Horizon. One of the Armies Å¿tood towards the EaÅ¿t, the other to the WeÅ¿t, faceing each other, both drawn up exactly in Battadia, and appearing Å¿o viÅ¿ibly that the Å¿pectators could diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the HorÅ¿e and Foot, diÅ¿cern the Several Brigades, and plainly Å¿ee their Trains of Artillery: ThoÅ¿e that firÅ¿t view'd this Å¿trange Å¿ight Å¿ummon their Neighbours to admire it, and in an hours Å¿pace people are Alarm'd round the Countrey, who get out of their Beds and HouÅ¿es, and with trembling behold this amazeing prodigy, which added more to their terror, when haveing appeared Å¿ome time in that poÅ¿ture, as braveing each other, both Armies on a Å¿udden ruÅ¿ht forwards with a Violent motion, and Å¿eem'd to meet and moÅ¿t furiouÅ¿ly engage each other, whereupon they heard whole Vallies of Cannons diÅ¿charg'd, and peals of musket Å¿hot, continually playing for above an hour; accompanied all that time with hideons Cries, and Å¿hreeks, howlings, Å¿ometimes like the Å¿hreeks of Women or Children, and at other times like that of men wounded, and giveing up their laÅ¿t Breath in Dying Groans.

This diÅ¿mal Airial Conflict continued with much fury till Sun-riÅ¿ing, both parties being Å¿o intermixt,
that it was impoÅ¿Å¿ible to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h which had the Victory, the whole Heavens appeared of a crimÅ¿on-dye, and overÅ¿pread with blood: and the continual FlaÅ¿hes made it Å¿eem like the Day of Doom, when the whole World Å¿hall become a Prey to the Element of Fire: It is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to imagine (much leÅ¿s expreÅ¿s) the ConÅ¿ternation of the People, who by thouÅ¿ands Å¿tood to behold this wonderful Spectacle, where their eyes and ears Encountred nothing but objects of Terror: At laÅ¿t the Sun being got above the Horizon, cauÅ¿ed all theÅ¿e Warlike PhantaÅ¿ms to diÅ¿apear, and Å¿oon after, the noiÅ¿e ceaÅ¿ed, and the Heavens put on their former friendly Countenance, which yet cannot wipe out thoÅ¿e ruful Characters of Fear, Affrightment, and DiÅ¿pair, imprinted on the dejected viÅ¿ages of the Spectators by this Prodigy of Horror.

About a week after, at Noon-day, no Cloud, Storm, or TempeÅ¿t appearing nigh, a moÅ¿t terrible Fiery red hot Bullet was obÅ¿erved by hundreds of people, to paÅ¿s through the Air a little higher than the tops of their houÅ¿es, but of a very vaÅ¿t bigneÅ¿s, and making a Å¿trange kind of hiÅ¿Å¿ing in its paÅ¿Å¿age, yet doing no hurt, but flying Å¿o Å¿everal miles directly EaÅ¿t; at laÅ¿t with a mighty noiÅ¿e, as if it would have rent the earth, it burÅ¿t into a thouÅ¿and pieces, which flaming and fluttering a while in the Air, vaniÅ¿ht.

Several other Å¿trange and prodigious Å¿ights have lately manifeÅ¿ted themÅ¿elves in divers parts of that Kingdom, the particulars whereof we Å¿hall here omit, and only obÅ¿erve that the fore-recited Aparences could not be the vain Chimera's of wanton Fancy, or depraved Conceits of melancholly heads, as
Children fancy they Å¿ee CaÅ¿tles, and men, and beaÅ¿ts, and other Å¿trange things Å¿ometimes in the Clouds, or a bright Fire; it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible Å¿uch a multitude of people Å¿hould all be cheated in their Å¿ences with one and the Å¿ame Imagination: nor was it their eyes only, but their ears too had a Å¿ufficient Å¿hare in this prodigious entertainment.

Let us not place God's immediate miraculous Admonitions to the account of common Secundary cauÅ¿es, nor argue againÅ¿t the reality of their Aparence, till we Å¿mart under the fury of their Significations, God has two fair Volumes, whereby he reveals his pleaÅ¿ure to the Sons of men, his Word, and his Works; Å¿ometimes he wooes us by the one, and Å¿ometimes warns us by the other: and thoÅ¿e that will neither obey his moÅ¿t profitable Precepts, nor regard his merciful Threatnings, deÅ¿ervedly become Objects of his Å¿evere JuÅ¿tice: who then Å¿ets up cruel and barbarous Nations (as Rods of his Anger) to Å¿courge them that vainly pride themÅ¿elves in the Title o â¢ ChriÅ¿tians, and yet Å¿urpaÅ¿s the worÅ¿t of Heathens in all kinds of Debauchery and WickedneÅ¿s.

As for the Å¿ignifications of theÅ¿e uncouth Apparences, we Å¿ay only in the words of the eldeÅ¿t of SybilsâCaelum Mars Solus habebit: It is obÅ¿ervable that the Male-effects of the three laÅ¿t Comets in 1965. are not to this day over-paÅ¿t: The Northern parts of the world have already been Å¿enÅ¿ible of the DiÅ¿aÅ¿ters thereby menaced: But we fear this cup of trembling muÅ¿t go round, and who knows but the Countries North and North-EaÅ¿t are deÅ¿igned next to pledge it: It is now a hundred years Å¿ince the famous New-Star in CaÅ¿Å¿iopia firÅ¿t appear'd to mortals; and it was the Judgement of the moÅ¿t Learned Ticho Brahe that
the Portents thereof would be chiefly viÅ¿ible about Å¿uch a period of time from thence, and in thoÅ¿e very Regions of Poland, RuÅ¿Å¿ia, or MuÅ¿covia: nor do the late frequent opoÅ¿itions of the two Superiors, Saturn and Jupiter imitate leÅ¿s than the Mid-wifeing Å¿ome eminent CataÅ¿trophes into the World: ThoÅ¿e that are acquainted with the Hermetick Learning can tell to what Angel the Government of Å¿ublunaries is moÅ¿t referrible, and the few vere Adepti, or Legitimate Sons of Art poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t of the true CabaliÅ¿tical AÅ¿trology, unÅ¿ullied by the vanities of the Aegyptians and Arabians, may give a rational Judgement on Å¿uch rare Phanomina as theÅ¿e, whilÅ¿t the vulgar ScioliÅ¿t flutters in a purblind Ignorance, and does but vend the follies of his frothy brain, inÅ¿tead of the Dictates of Art.
